newsitem.title: UK: EMU stability pact may worsen recessions - report.
newsitem.headline: EMU stability pact may worsen recessions - report.

text.p: Strict rules governing budget deficits under a future European monetary union (EMU), recently negotiated by European heads of state in Dublin, could make recessions longer and deeper, a report said on Friday.
Professor Barry Eichengreen of University of California said countries should be given more leeway to run higher deficits when unemployment is high.

"The Excessive Budget Procedure (ECP) of the Maastricht Treaty and the Stability Pact negotiated at Dublin threaten to hamstring fiscal policy," he said in a report in the National Institute of Economic and Social Research's latest quarterly report.
Under the Stability Pact, countries included in monetary union will be fined for running deficits higher than 3.0 percent of GDP.

"By creating a structure that constrains both the monetary and fiscal independence of the EMU member states, the Maastricht Treaty threatens to create an exceedingly rigid and fragile European economy," Eichengreen said.

The rules would prevent governments from spending more and cutting taxes at times when unemployment is rising, leaving them no means to stimulate their economies and the labour markets, since monetary policy will be set by the European Central Bank.
His solution is to apply the rules of the stability pact not to the actual budget defict, but to one constantly adjusted for employment levels, which he calls the constant employment budget deficit.
